com.timesten.jdbc.connectionpool
Class TimesTenConnectionPool

java.lang.Object
  com.timesten.jdbc.connectionpool.TimesTenConnectionPool

public final class TimesTenConnectionPool
extends java.lang.Object

Represents a Timesten Connection Pool. This class instantiates a TimesTen connection pool i.e. a pool of TimestenPooledConnection objects.

Field Detail

TTCP_SQLSTATE

public static final java.lang.String TTCP_SQLSTATE
SQLSTATE value used for all SQLExceptions originating from TimesTenConnectionPool.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

TTCP_ERR_STILL_IN_TRANSACTION

public static final int TTCP_ERR_STILL_IN_TRANSACTION
Connection Pool Error - Still In Transaction. A SQLException with this error code is thrown if an attempt is made to release a connection (return it to the pool) while the connection has an open transaction. The application should finish the transaction by either comitting or rolling back and then retry the releaseConnection call.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

TTCP_ERR_INVALID_PARAMETER

public static final int TTCP_ERR_INVALID_PARAMETER
Connection Pool Error - Invalid Parameter. A SQLException with this error code is thrown in some cases when an invalid parameter is passed to a connection pool method.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

TTCP_ERR_STATE_ERROR

public static final int TTCP_ERR_STATE_ERROR
Connection Pool Error - State Error. A SQLException with this error code is thrown if a method is called which is invalid for the current state of the connection pool. For example, attemtping to initialise() an already initialised connection pool.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

TTCP_ERR_NOT_ALLOWED

public static final int TTCP_ERR_NOT_ALLOWED
Connection Pool Error - Not Allowed. A SQLException with this error code is thrown if a method is called which is not supported. A TimesTenPooledConnection only supports a limited subset of the operations that are allowed on a normal connection. Operations which are not commonly used, or which are anyway not supported by Timesten, may return this error.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

TTCP_ERR_RESIZE_ERROR

public static final int TTCP_ERR_RESIZE_ERROR
Connection Pool Error - Resize Error. A resizePool() operation failed due to some lower level error. The pool may have been partially resized.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

TTCP_ERR_NOT_IN_USE

public static final int TTCP_ERR_NOT_IN_USE
Connection Pool Error - Connection not in use. An attempt was made to release a connection that was not 'in use'.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

TTCP_ERR_PREPARE_ERROR

public static final int TTCP_ERR_PREPARE_ERROR
Connection Pool Error - Prepare Error. A statement prepare failed. The chained exception will give the underlying cause.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

TTCP_ERR_POOL_DEAD

public static final int TTCP_ERR_POOL_DEAD
Connection Pool Error - Pool is Dead. An unrecoverable error has occurred. The pool is unusable until after a successful shutdown() and initialise().

See Also:
Constant Field Values

TTCP_ERR_INTERNAL

public static final int TTCP_ERR_INTERNAL
Connection Pool Error - Internal Error. An unrecoverable internal error has occurred. The pool is unusable until after a successful shutdown() and initialise().

See Also:
Constant Field Values

TTCP_ERR_FAILOVER

public static final int TTCP_ERR_FAILOVER
Failover in progress. A failover operation is in progress for the pool. No other operations are allowed until the failover has completed.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

TTCP_ERR_CONN_INVALID

public static final int TTCP_ERR_CONN_INVALID
Connection invalid due to failover. This connection is invalid due to an in progress failover. Return the connection to the pool and obtain a new connection after the failover has completed.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

TTCP_ERR_STMT_INVALID

public static final int TTCP_ERR_STMT_INVALID
Statement invalid due to failover. This statement is invalid due to an in progress failover. Return the associated connection to the pool and obtain a new connection after the failover has completed.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

public static final java.lang.String TIMESTEN_DIRECT_URL_PREFIX
JDBC URL prefix for a direct mode connection.

See Also:

JDBC URL prefix for a client/server connection.

See Also:

Constructor Detail

TimesTenConnectionPool

public TimesTenConnectionPool(int numConnections)
Creates a connection pool initially containing 'numConnections' connections. The initial state of the pool is !initialised, suspended, quiescent. Before the pool can be used, the application must first initialise it and set the value for the URL

Parameters:
numConnections - The number of connections in the pool
See Also:
initialise(java.lang.String, boolean), resizePool(int)
Method Detail

getConnection

public final TimesTenPooledConnection getConnection()
                                             throws java.sql.SQLException
Obtains a connection from the pool without waiting. If no connection is currently available (pool suspended, no free connections, failover in progress) then immediately returns null.

Returns:
A TimesTenPooledConnection object for an open connection.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
getConnectionWait(), getConnectionWait(int), releaseConnection(com.timesten.jdbc.connectionpool.TimesTenPooledConnection)

getConnectionWait

public final TimesTenPooledConnection getConnectionWait()
                                                 throws java.sql.SQLException
Obtains a connection from the pool, waiting indefinitely. If no connection is currently available (pool suspended, no free connections, failover in progress) then waits until one is available. Could wait indefinitely, so use with caution.

Returns:
A TimesTenPooledConnection object for an open connection.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
getConnection(), getConnectionWait(int), releaseConnection(com.timesten.jdbc.connectionpool.TimesTenPooledConnection)

getConnectionWait

public final TimesTenPooledConnection getConnectionWait(int millis)
                                                 throws java.sql.SQLException
Obtains a connection from the pool, waiting for a specified time. If no connection is currently available (pool suspended, no free connections, failover in progress) then waits until one is available. If no connection is available within the specified number of milliseconds, returns null.

Passing a negative value for 'millis' results in the same behaviour as getConnectionWait(). Passing a zero value for 'millis' results in the same behaviour as getConnection().

Parameters:
millis - The maximum time (in milliseconds) to wait for a connection to be available.
Returns:
A TimesTenPooledConnection object for an open connection.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
getConnection(), getConnectionWait(), releaseConnection(com.timesten.jdbc.connectionpool.TimesTenPooledConnection)

releaseConnection

public final void releaseConnection(TimesTenPooledConnection ttconn)
                             throws java.sql.SQLException
Returns a connection to the pool. The application has the responsibility to ensure that the connection does not have an active transaction when it is returned. Essentially this means that the last thing the application does on the connection before returning it must be either commit() or rollback(). Attempting to return a connection with an active transaction will result in an exception being thrown. Once the application has returned the connection it must not perform any further operations on that connection, or on any of the associated statements retrieved via getPreparedStmt(), getCallableStmt(), getStmt() and should discard any references it has to those objects.

Parameters:
ttconn - A TimesTenPooledConnection object previously obtained from the pool using one of the getConnection() methods.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
getConnection(), getConnectionWait(), getConnectionWait(int)

initialise

public final void initialise(java.lang.String url,
                             boolean enablefailover)
                      throws java.sql.SQLException
Initialises the pool for use. Sets the values for the URL and whether failover handling should be enabled. After the method returns, the pool is initialised but still suspended and quiescent. Typically the application will then add various statements to the pool using addXXXXStatement() before enabling it for use via enable().

Parameters:
url - The TimesTen JDBC connection URL for the pool.
enablefailover - Indicates if the pool should automatically handle connection failover. Automatic failover handling is only supported for client/server connections. If this parameter is passed as 'true' for a direct mode pool it is silently changed to false.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
shutdown()

shutdown

public final void shutdown()
                    throws java.sql.SQLException
Shuts the pool down and releases its resources. Once shutdown, it can not then be used until it has again been initialised. In order for the shutdown to succeed, the pool must be in the quiescent state (no active connections). Shutting down an already shutdown pool, or a not yet initialised pool, is considered successful.

Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
initialise(java.lang.String, boolean), suspend(), isQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(int)

resizePool

public final int resizePool(int count)
                     throws java.sql.SQLException
Change the number of connections in the pool. The number can be increased or decreased. Count is the absolute number of connections desired in the pool. If an error is encountered during the resizing, the pool may have been partially resized. The return value indicates how many connections are now in the pool. The pool must be in the quiescent state for this call to succeed.

Parameters:
count - The new number of connections in the pool. This can be larger or smaller than the current number of connections.
Returns:
The number of connections in the pool after the (possibly partial) resize.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
suspend(), isQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(int)

addPreparedStatement

public final void addPreparedStatement(java.lang.String label,
                                       java.lang.String sql)
                                throws java.sql.SQLException
Adds a prepared statement to all connections in the pool. The value of 'label' is used to retrieve the statement when the application needs to use it, and must be unique. If you add a statement with the same label value as an existing statement then it will replace the original statement. The pool must be in the quiescent state for this call to succeed.

Parameters:
label - A (unique) label used to identify the statement.
sql - The SQL statement text.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
removePreparedStmt(java.lang.String), suspend(), isQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(int)

addPreparedStatement

public final void addPreparedStatement(java.lang.String label,
                                       java.lang.String sql,
                                       java.lang.String[] opthints)
                                throws java.sql.SQLException
Adds a prepared statement, with optimiser hints, to all connections in the pool. The value of 'label' is used to retrieve the statement when the application needs to use it, and must be unique. If you add a statement with the same label value as an existing statement then it will replace the original statement. Multiple optimiser hints may be passed and will be applied to the prepared statement. The pool must be in the quiescent state for this call to succeed.

Parameters:
label - A (unique) label used to identify the statement.
sql - The SQL statement text.
opthints - An array of optimiser hints. For example: { "call ttOptSetFlag('Scan',0)", "call ttOptSetFlag('Hash',1)" }
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
removePreparedStmt(java.lang.String), suspend(), isQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(int)

removePreparedStmt

public final void removePreparedStmt(java.lang.String label)
                              throws java.sql.SQLException
Removes a prepared statement from all connections in the pool. The value of 'label' identifies the statement to be removed. Removing a label value that does not exist is considered successful. The pool must be in the quiescent state for this call to succeed.

Parameters:
label - Identifies the statement to be removed.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
addPreparedStatement(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), suspend(), isQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(int)

addCallableStatement

public final void addCallableStatement(java.lang.String label,
                                       java.lang.String sql)
                                throws java.sql.SQLException
Adds a callable statement to all connections in the pool. The value of 'label' is used to retrieve the statement when the application needs to use it, and must be unique. If you add a statement with the same label value as an existing statement then it will replace the original statement. The pool must be in the quiescent state for this call to succeed.

Parameters:
label - A (unique) label used to identify the statement.
sql - The SQL statement text.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
removeCallableStmt(java.lang.String), suspend(), isQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(int)

removeCallableStmt

public final void removeCallableStmt(java.lang.String label)
                              throws java.sql.SQLException
Removes a callable statement from all connections in the pool. The value of 'label' identifies the statement to be removed. Removing a label value that does not exist is considered successful. The pool must be in the quiescent state for this call to succeed.

Parameters:
label - Identifies the statement to be removed.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
addCallableStatement(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), suspend(), isQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(int)

addStatement

public final void addStatement(java.lang.String label)
                        throws java.sql.SQLException
Adds a statement to all connections in the pool. The value of 'label' is used to retrieve the statement when the application needs to use it, and must be unique. If you add a statement with the same label value as an existing statement then it will replace the original statement. The pool must be in the quiescent state for this to succeed.

Parameters:
label - A (unique) label used to identify the statement.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
removeStmt(java.lang.String), suspend(), isQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(int)

removeStmt

public final void removeStmt(java.lang.String label)
                      throws java.sql.SQLException
Removes a statement from all connections in the pool. The value of 'label' identifies the statement to be removed. Removing a label value that does not exist is considered successful. The pool must be in the quiescent state for this call to succeed.

Parameters:
label - Identifies the statement to be removed.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
addStatement(java.lang.String), suspend(), isQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(int)

suspend

public final boolean suspend()
                      throws java.sql.SQLException
Sets the pool state to 'suspended'. While it is suspended, the pool will not give out any new connections (via getConnection() and its variants) but will allow currently active connections to be returned via releaseConnection(). Once the last active connection is returned, the pool enters the 'quiescent' state. If there are no active connections at the time suspend() is called, then the pool immediately becomes quiescent and suspend() returns true. Otherwise, suspend() returns false and you must check for the pool having become quiescent using the isQuiescent() method.

Returns:
True if pool is already quiescent, false if not.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
enable(), isQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(int)

enable

public final void enable()
                  throws java.sql.SQLException
Clears the 'suspended' state for the pool allowing it to be used. A pool can only be enabled if it has already been initialised. Once the pool is enabled, connections can be obtained using the getConnection() methods.

Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
suspend()

isInitialised

public final boolean isInitialised()
Indicates if the pool is in the 'initialised' state. A pool must be initialised before most other methods can be used.

Returns:
True if pool is initialised, false otherwise.
See Also:
initialise(java.lang.String, boolean), shutdown()

isAlive

public final boolean isAlive()
Indicates if the pool is alive. A pool must be alive for most methods to be used. A pool will become 'dead' if a non-recoverable error is encountered. In this case the pool must be shutdown using the shutdown() method and then re-initialised using the initialise() method.

Returns:
True if pool is alive, false if it is dead.
See Also:
initialise(java.lang.String, boolean), shutdown()

isSuspended

public final boolean isSuspended()
Indicates if the pool is in the 'suspended' state. When in the suspended state, the pool will not give out any new connections. It will however allow the return of currently in use connections.

Returns:
True if pool is suspended, false otherwise.
See Also:
suspend()

isQuiescent

public final boolean isQuiescent()
Indicates if the pool is in the 'quiescent' state. A pool enters the 'quiescent' state when it is in the 'suspended' state and the last active connection is returned to the pool. The pool remains in the quiescent state until it is re-enabled and a connection is given out via one of the getConnection methods.

Returns:
True if pool is quiescent, false otherwise.
See Also:
suspend(), waitforQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(int)

isInFailover

public final boolean isInFailover()
Indicates if the pool is currently processing a failover.

Returns:
True if pool is currently processing a failover, false otherwise.
See Also:
waitforFailover(), waitforFailover(int)

waitforQuiescent

public final boolean waitforQuiescent()
                               throws java.sql.SQLException
Waits for pool to enter 'quiescent' state. Will wait for ever if required.

Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
suspend(), isQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent(int)

waitforQuiescent

public final boolean waitforQuiescent(int millis)
                               throws java.sql.SQLException
Waits for pool to enter 'quiescent' state. Will wait at for at most 'millis' milliseconds. Immediately returns true if pool becomes quiescent during this time. If pool does not become quiescent, returns false.

Parameters:
millis - Maximum number of milliseconds to wait. If value passed is < 0 then behaviour is the same as waitforQuiescent(). If value passed is 0, behaviour is same as isQuiescent().
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
suspend(), isQuiescent(), waitforQuiescent()

waitforFailover

public final boolean waitforFailover()
                              throws java.sql.SQLException
Waits for pool to complete a failover. Will wait for ever if required.

Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
isInFailover(), waitforFailover(int)

waitforFailover

public final boolean waitforFailover(int millis)
                              throws java.sql.SQLException
Waits for pool to complete a failover. Will wait at for at most 'millis' milliseconds. Immediately returns true if failover completes during this time. If failover does not complete during this time, returns false.

Parameters:
millis - Maximum number of milliseconds to wait. If value passed is < 0 then behaviour is the same as waitforFailover(). If value passed is 0, behaviour is same as isInFailover().
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException
See Also:
isInFailover(), waitforFailover()

isClientServer

public final boolean isClientServer()
Indicates if this pool is a client/server pool or a direct mode pool.

Returns:
True if pool is client/server, false otherwise. If the pool has not been initialised, returns false.

getURL

public final java.lang.String getURL()
Returns the URL value for this pool.

Returns:
URL value set for pool. If the pool has not yet been initialised, returns null.
See Also:
initialise(java.lang.String, boolean)

getPoolSize

public final int getPoolSize()
Returns the total number of connections in the pool.

Returns:
Number of connections in pool.

getFreePoolSize

public final int getFreePoolSize()
Returns the number of free connections in the pool.

Returns:
Number of free connections in pool as of the time this method is called. If the pool has not been initialised, returns 0.
